Posts.Content: Oct 21, 2012 06:15PM rgiuff wrote: Seeay, I'm not understanding your post at all.  My tumor was ER+ and I did tamoxifen, which blocks estrogen.
Posts.Title: removal of ovaries vs lupron 131mom exercise_guru

Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2012 06:32AM - edited Nov 16, 2012 06:39AM by rgiuff Eileen, I can absolutely relate to your feelings.  I was only a Stage 1.  So because of that, I felt that the benefit to me of hormonal therapy was not huge.  Not sure what your current stage is, but sounds like it's early if they are doing oncotype.  From the start, I resented the idea that a natural hormone that is good for our bodies and quality of life, could be the culprit, and I didn't completely buy the idea.  I didn't really want to do tamoxifen, but did for 3 years just to play it safe and because it didn't take away my estrogen, just kept it away from the breast cancer cells.  I was perimenopausal and moved into being postmenopausal while I was on it.  But the whole time, I kept wishing that I could remain premenopausal, because I didn't like the changes that I was experiencing with menopause.  The drop in sex drive, the increased wrinkling of skin, the sleep disruption from hot flashes, and the aches and pains.  It was difficult to tell what effects were from natural changes and which were from tamoxifen.  After stopping it, some libido problems resolved a little, the vulval dryness along with all the vaginal discharge improved, and sleep has improved a lot.  Sleep was a big issue for me! I started an AI about 4 months after stopping tamoxifen, mainly to appease my oncologist, but stopped after only 2 months due to big problems with getting to sleep, foot pain like I've never experienced before, and worries about it prematurely aging me internally, as well as externally.  Heart disease and strokes also run in my family.  So I decided that I was done and would keep whatever estrogen I was still making, thank you very much!  I feel that something goes wrong with DNA to start the breast cancer process, don't think it's natural estrogen that causes the problem.  I feel that the issue is more of what is in our environment, the xenoestrogens that are sprayed onto our foods, and in so many household and cosmetic products, the chemicals in foods.  So I've chosen to eat mainly whole foods, organic as much as I can afford, now buy skin creams without parabens, and exercise regularly, as well as have cut down on alcohol.  And studies have been published showing that alcohol and exercise do impact the recurrence of breast cancer.  I would love to see studies comparing these natural factors against the pharmaceutical drugs.  If you want to go the pharmeceutical route, there are other drugs that work similarly to tamoxifen, that have been studied and approved for advanced breast cancers, but I have seen on these boards that more and more premenopausal early stage patients are being prescribed them.  Fareston is one of them, and I can't remember the names of others.  You could ask your Onc about them.
Posts.Title: removal of ovaries vs lupron 131mom exercise_guru

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2010 06:02PM rgiuff wrote: Robin, having such an early stage cancer, I'm wondering why you can't just take tamoxifen.  Why is your doctor recommending removing or suppressing ovaries?  When you don't have functioning ovaries, you lose not only most of your estrogen production, but a great amt.of your testosterone production as well.  This is the hormone responsible for libido and enjoying our sex lives.  I have not done this.  It was never suggested for me by any of the Oncs or other doctors that I saw, but know women who have removed ovaries and they do complain about vaginal dryness and some loss of libido and sensation.  They all had more advanced stages of BC, so this is why their docs recommended this procedure.  So I'm always surprised to hear of women with early stage cancers who have this procedure recommended to them.  I would read up on the long term effects before doing anything as drastic as removing ovaries.
Posts.Title: removal of ovaries vs lupron 131mom exercise_guru

Posts.Content: Oct 5, 2012 11:42AM - edited Oct 5, 2012 11:47AM by rgiuff Irmodm, not understanding why you would need to remove ovaries.  I was premenopausal at diagnosis.  The only thing ever suggested was tamoxifen after I had my lumpectomy followed by radiation.  I never had any type of ovarian suppression, nor did I have any chemo.  When I commented to my Onc about how many women seemed to be getting oophorectomies to treat breast cancer, he stated that that was definitely something he would not suggest for me.  I did become postmenopausal during the 3 years I was on tamoxifen.  You've done chemo already, which has a high probability of having shut down your ovaries anyway.  Even if your periods were to come back, could you do tamoxifen alone without the lupron, or is there a reason why you can't take it? Unless there is a risk for ovarian cancer, removing your ovaries seems pretty aggressive to me.  Your GYN does earn a living doing these types of surgeries, just a thought.
Posts.Title: removal of ovaries vs lupron 131mom exercise_guru

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2009 01:53PM rgiuff wrote: I was diagnosed April 6, 2008.  Spent time seeing a few different surgeons to get more than 1 opinion.  I only ended up with a lumpectomy, but if I would have needed a masectomy, I would have spent even more time seeing plastic surgeons as well. because I would have wanted to coordinate all the surgeons and have masectomy and reconstruction all in the same surgery.  Initially I felt overwhelmed at the choices and needed time to absorb all the information and make sure that I was sure of my decision.  I also had problems with getting my insurance to approve the MRI that was ordered,   So things took awhile but could have taken even longer.  And people around me were more nervous than I was, inquiring constantly about the delay.  I'm glad that I didn't let anybody pressure me into making a hasty decision that I later could have regretted.  I had my surgery May 21, 2008,  after picking the surgeon that I was most impressed with.  I was very concerned about the cosmetic result, being my breasts were small to begin with.  And I was concerned about lymphedema, so I wanted someone who was experienced with doing the sentinel node biopsy.  So I'm glad I shopped around and found a surgeon who specialized in breast surgery only, because a year later, except for a small, very faded scar, I can't tell any difference in my breast at all.
Posts.Title: How long between diagnosis and surgery or treatment? Anxiousmama katiec

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2009 08:51AM - edited Dec 30, 2009 08:55AM by rgiuff My Onc said flaxseed is fine, and soy in moderation.  I've read more good than bad about flaxseed and I personally am convinced that it's a good thing to use, studies have shown that it's Omega 3 properties are beneficial to cardiac health, skin, joints, and it's phytoestrogenic properties do similar things to what tamoxifen does.  It's a weak estrogen which can crowd out the stronger estrogens.  I find it's also good for digestive system, prevents constipation. From what I've read about soy, the fermented forms, such as tofu, tempeh, and miso, are beneficial, and the concentrated forms, such as those found in supplements and soy powders, are to be avoided.  And it's important that it be organic.  If it's not, it can be full of estrogenic pesticides.  Also, too much soy can affect the thyroid function. Most of the best, clean foods are phytoestrogenic, legumes, many fruits and vegetables, seeds, grains, so trying to avoid them, may be detrimental to our health in other areas.
Posts.Title: No soy? kimber3006 kimber3006

Posts.Content: Jul 21, 2009 03:16PM rgiuff wrote: Sometimes microcalcifications are benign and sometimes they can turn into something worse.  So waiting 6 months is the usual routine to see if anything worse develops.
Posts.Title: 6 month wait okay? KimberleyGL cookiemom

Posts.Content: Jun 9, 2009 05:47PM rgiuff wrote: Ssimmons, I was in your situation about a year ago.  People are always going to have conflicting advice, so you can't base your decisions on what others think..  You are the one who has to live with the results of your decision.  I had initially thought that since my breasts were small, a lumpectomy would really reduce the size, so maybe it was better to get them taken off and get reconstruction.  But my surgeon assured me that I only needed a lumpectomy and that since the tumor was so small, and located high up on my breast, and the fact that she uses oncoplastic techniques, that I would have a good result.   And I started thinking about other things, like the loss of nipple sensation,   possible complications with a reconstruction, and in the end, decided that I wanted to keep my own breasts and would rethink the masectomy option if the cancer ever came back.  I felt that  a masectomy was a drastic fear based option and that If I went that route, it would be irreversible.  And I am not a drastic type of person, I like to do things calmly.  And I didn't want to have to worry about implant complications as that would have been my only reconstruction option, since I have no belly fat and hate the idea of cutting into other areas of my body for donor tissue.

Posts.Content: Sep 12, 2009 06:40PM rgiuff wrote: Klawless, ask for a copy of your pathology report from the place that did the biopsy.  Tell them you need it to bring for your second opinion visits.  This will have the Stage, grade, and whether or not  they found estrogen/progesterone receptors on the tumor.  This is needed by any doctor you go to to help make surgical decisions.  You also need your Mammo and Sono films and reports to bring with you as well.  I just asked for all these things and they gave them all to me after I signed a form.  If nobody will hand these items to you directly, you can tell them you need them sent to the 2nd opinion doctor, and this they have to do.  It is perfectly normal in this situation to be getting other opinions.  But they should give them to you if you ask because they are your medical records.
Posts.Title: recieved 2 different diagnoses today... Klawless9 swest

Posts.Content: Sep 24, 2009 01:19AM - edited Sep 24, 2009 01:51AM by rgiuff Kendall, the MRI result is very important here.  If you want minimal surgery, and only want lumpectomy, you need to make sure that that is even an option.  If you end up with masectomy, and you are very thin, you most likely won't be eligible for the procedures that involve taking other body parts to make breasts.  You'd be more likely to end up with the expanders which are filled at intervals with solution until the skin has stretched to the size that the implant needs.  Then the expander is replaced with the implant in an exchange surgery. If you are able to have just a lumpectomy and save the nipple, but decide to go with masectomy, you should ask the breast surgeon if you can have skin sparing/and or nipple sparing technique.  This would be the ideal for better cosmetic result.  You should also ask PS to see pictures of the different plastic surgical procedures and their outcomes.  If you turn out to be BRCA positive, you will have to see a genetic counselor who would guide you in all the options.  Some women go for the prophylactic double masectomy, but many don't because screening for breast cancer is very good.  So it would be good to decide which route you would want before your surgery.  But if the choice is too overwhelming, you don't have to necessarily decide right away.  You could have a lumpectomy if you're eligible for that, and then later decide on masectomies if any signs of trouble start brewing in the future.  Prophylactic double masectomy is the most drastic surgery, but some women do it for peace of mind/and or for cosmetic reasons.  You want to know that you thought the decision over thoroughly, and feel content that you made the right one.  Some women do have regrets later over their decision, whether conservative or drastic.  The more information you obtain ahead of time, the more likely you will know everything you need to know to make the right decision. Also, for me money was very important.  Because I went with all doctors and hospital that are in network, my surgery, radiation, tests, procedures, doctor visits, and medication have all cost me nothing.  A friend of mine, who felt she had to have the best of everything, and went out of network to Sloan Kettering, is now years later, many thousands of dollars in debt.   I wouldn't even give it a second thought about offending the surgeon.   They know that patients go for second opinions, and as mentioned by an earlier post, it's the office staff, that you would speak to anyway, not the doctor. You have to worry about what will work best for you and the doctor will always have many other patients.

Posts.Title: 5 Yrs Lupron & Tamoxifen - then kids??? Bridanomor rgiuff

Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2009 10:40AM rgiuff wrote: Oncs are usually the ones who recommend this, so if yours is saying no, then there is no need.  They don't usually remove them from postmenopausal women because they are no longer putting out hormones.  The only women I know who have had them removed, have all been premenopausal unless they were being removed for some other reason, such as being BRCA+.  Many have them removed so that they can go on Arimidex, but if you are already on it, then they must have found you to be already in menopause.
Posts.Title: Remove ovaries after treatment, Yes or No? Jean09 Jean09

Posts.Content: Jun 18, 2011 07:56PM rgiuff wrote: Just one thought to add, a consideration which was very important to me in making a decision, was the loss of sensation.  I chose lumpectomy over masectomy because I did not want to lose the sensation of my real nipple.  If I had to have a masectomy, I would definitely not have the healthy breast removed.
Posts.Title: Bilateral vs. Unilateral Mastectomy WorkingMom10 habbott

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2009 09:58PM - edited Sep 11, 2009 09:59PM by rgiuff Kendall, I just saw all your posts.  So sorry you have to go through all this so young.  I see that you live in Westbury,  I'm in Hicksville.  I went for 3 different opinions before I had my lumpectomy.  I wanted to see what surgery each doctor recommended and how the cosmetic result would be after the surgery.  Maybe you should get more than 1 opinion for the surgery.  I took my time because these are long term decisions and I also had HIP insurance which many doctors don't take.  Can you contact your insurance and find out which doctors are in the plan? If you end up needing masectomy, reconstruction can be done during the same surgery, but you have to see plastic surgeons and arrange for both breast and plastic surgeons to be there during the one surgery.  There are also 2 different routes to go as far as reconstruction goes.  There are procedures using your own tissue, such as muscle and fat from the abdominal area, or there are implants.  If you do end up needing a masectomy, you should make an appt. with a plastic surgeon prior to the masectomy to discuss all your reconstructive options. Once finished with surgery,  I got the pathology report from the lumpectomy and brought that to my 1st Oncologist visit, along with all my mammo, ultrasound and MRI reports.  From there, based on all the data, and an Oncotype DX test, which was sent out to determine whether or not I needed chemo, treatment decisions were made.  I didn't need chemo, but had radiation and take tamoxifen now.   Whether or not you need chemo will depend on what type of tumor you have, if it's DCIS(ductal carcinoma in situ), you wouldn't need chemo.  If it's invasive,  you may need chemo, many factors, such as your age, stage of cancer, and whether lymph nodes are involved, are taken into consideration when deciding this.   For CAT scans of chest, abdomen, and pelvis, they should be able to do all of them in one appt. You can ask.   You may have to drink some contrast solution right beforehand, which is not so bad.  It justs helps them to better see your insides.  For the bone scan, they will inject some dye into your vein, and you will have to wait a few hours after that for them to do the scan, so you will need time to get all these tests done.  None of them are painful. You have a lot being thrown at you right now and it can be overwhelming, so it's important not to be rushed into hasty decisions and to take the time now to research and get second opinions, so that you can later feel that the best decisions were made.
Posts.Title: recieved 2 different diagnoses today... Klawless9 swest

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2009 11:57AM rgiuff wrote: Klawless, I have small barely A cup breasts and my major concern was to avoid masectomy and to have a good cosmetic result.  I knew that I didn't like any of the reconstruction options which involved taking part of my muscles from somewhere else on my body, and implants make me a little nervous with all that could go wrong with them and the fact that future reoccurrances could be harder to detect.  But I was concerned that there would be nothing left of my breast once they took out the lump.  So I knew I had to find a really good breast surgeon. I researched which hospitals have the best reputations and the most advanced techniques for dealing with cancers and of course, the best ones were in the city.  Sloan Kettering doesn't participate in my insurance (HIP}, so that one was out, but Columbia Presbyterian is in my plan, so I made an appt. there with the one surgeon who took my insurance.  It turned out she only does breasts and she uses the oncoplastic technique, which impressed me, (This is a technique where the surgeon moves over some of the breast tissue adjacent to the tumor and uses it to fill in the dent caused by the lumpectomy). My other major concern with the surgery was not having lymph nodes removed, because as a nurse, I've seen lymphedema in patients and it's not pretty.  I wanted to be sure that the doctor I picked was skilled at doing Sentinel node biopsy, where they only remove the 1st node (sentinel node) to which lymph would drain, and if this node is clear, the theory is that the rest would be clear as well.   If that one is positive, then they would go in and remove the whole group of axillary nodes. I also saw 2 surgeons from Long Island, but was more impressed by the one at Columbia, so I went with her.  I found some of my doctors at Newsday.com/news/health/doctors.  Newsday has a feature called Castle Connolly Top Doctors where you can search for a doctor based on specialty and hospital, and it gives phone numbers, and tells you what insurances they take and at what schools and hospitals they got their education and training.  The website is :  Newsday/com/news/health/doctors.  These doctors are voted best by their peers. I found my oncologist this way and he is here on Long Island.  I didn't want to keep traipsing into the city if I turned out to need chemo, and also, my oncology visits are every 3 months.  He also recommended my radiation oncologist and for that I definitely wanted to stay local, as it was every day for 6 weeks.   I did see one Medical Oncologist at Columbia just to compare her treatment plan with the doctors here on Long Island and they all had pretty much the same plan for after surgery. As far as the tumor size goes, they make the final determination when they actually remove the tumor.  I was told mine was 1cm, after the lumpectomy, it was determined to be .9cm, so just 1mm smaller.   If you have any questions about doctors I've seen, you can PM me.
Posts.Title: recieved 2 different diagnoses today... Klawless9 swest

Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2013 03:15PM - edited Dec 12, 2013 03:15PM by rgiuff Flyjune, I am over 5 years out from left lumpectomy and 6 weeks of radiation, done at age 47.  I remember the techs were very strict about positioning me and making sure I stayed still and would tell me when to breathe. I had absolutely no side effects at the time, nor have I had any later problems from it. I am very happy to have kept my natural breast.  Although small in size, I've always liked the shape of my breasts and didn't want to deal with the unknown of reconstructed breasts. And maybe even more importantly,  I got to keep the sensation of my real nipples.  Since going through menopause,  other areas seem to have lost some sensitivity,  but strangely enough, not my nipples. If anything,  they've become more of a help than ever in contributing to sexual sensations.  At this point, were I ever to have to lose my breasts,  I think I would be devastated!

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2010 04:14PM rgiuff wrote: Can't understand why she would need to have her uterus removed, especially if she is not taking tamoxifen and has no uterine problems.  Even the ovaries don't necessarily have to be removed.  There are drugs that suppress the ovaries and that could put her into a menopausal state (if she is not there already due to the chemo), so that she would be able to take an aromotase inhibitor.  Oophorectomy is an irreversible procedure that can negatively affect many other body systems (cardiac, bone, mental, sexual).  Has she gone for second opinions regarding the need for this surgery?
Posts.Title: Hysterectomy jppco_5 rgiuff

Posts.Content: May 13, 2012 02:52AM - edited May 13, 2012 02:53AM by rgiuff I'm 51 now, was diagnosed 4 years ago  and was newly perimenopausal at the time.  Oncotype score came back as a 14.  I did 6 weeks of rads after a lumpectomy with SNB, and then tamoxifen for 3 years, which I just stopped 3 months ago.  I did not have chemo, nor was it even recommended, probably due to my being stage 1, grade 1.  I've changed my lifestyle to include exercise several times a week and added in a lot more fruits and vegetables, and cut out many of the bad carbs and fats.  I've been fine for the past 4 years.
Posts.Title: In your 40's with low Oncotype score, what was your decision? gracebead p22nut5

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2011 10:01PM rgiuff wrote: Never heard that before Lago about the vaginal births.  How do vaginal births protect us from atrophy?  Pixelpup, your Onc sounds like a tyrant.  Maybe you'd be better off switching to someone else.  Are you currently taking an aromotase inhibitor?  On tamoxifen, even if there is a lot of estrogen floating around your system, the tamoxifen will block it from the breast cancer cells.  But if on the AIs, even though they drive estrogen down to almost 0, I guess your Onc is thinking, whatever is there will go to the BC cells?  But there are studies out there showing that starting vaginal estrogens initially causes an estrogen spike, but later once the local tissue plumps up, much less of it gets into the circulation.

Posts.Title: Lumpectomy with radiation, but no hormonal threrapy elimar PauldingMom

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2010 11:19PM rgiuff wrote: It's absolutely a side effect of tamoxifen,  it's one of the major listed side effects and I can tell you personally that for me, it goes in cycles.  I can go several weeks with no discharge and then for a few months, it's just constant.   It's always clear, and yes I have the same sensation that it's my period starting because a good amt. will come out sometimes.   I often have to wear pantiliners because of it.  It can get very annoying sometimes, but I look at it this way, it beats having the vaginal dryness that women on AIs get. I believe it happens because tamoxifen is estrogenic to the whole genital system, causing more buildup of cells in the uterus, so I figure, it's just some of those excess cells shedding?
Posts.Title: Clear, Spontaneous Vaginal Discharge - Tamoxifen SE? bejuce BouncingBetties

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2010 10:55AM rgiuff wrote: Cake, are you on tamoxifen?  I've been on it since Nov 2008.  It's a rare occasion now for me to get a period, just had 1 in Jan, then one in Feb after almost 10 months without one.  But I do find that sometimes I get the feelings that one is coming on, but then nothing happens.  I also get a heavy feeling in my pelvis, which seems to come and go in cycles.  I had a transvaginal ultrasound in Sept and everything was fine.  I have another one coming up in a couple of weeks, but I'm not worried.  I know that tamoxifen can build up the uterine lining, so I attribute a lot ot these sensations to that.  I actually feel that the sensations have diminished since I had those 2 recent periods, I'm glad that my uterus shed some of that lining!
Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker

Posts.Content: Nov 12, 2009 12:42PM rgiuff wrote: Hi everyone.  I was diagnosed April of 2008 and had lumpectomy  with SNB 6 weeks later, no chemo, radiation finished over a year ago.  Now on tamoxifen about a year, but stopped it for 6 weeks over the summer (my own decision) due to the intense hot flashes and sexual side effects.  I'm now back on it for the past 3 months, much to my Onc's relief.  A couple of months ago, my hot flashes just started to die down and now they are almost nonexistent.  I no longer have any side effects worth mentioning, just little annoying things that cyclically pop up here and there.  My 1st transvaginal sono was 6 weeks ago and so far, no ovarian or uterine problems. My last period was 8 months ago and my Onc wants me to switch to AIs once I'm completely postmenopausal, but I have no desire to take meds that completely stop my body from making any estrogen.  I feel that with such an early stage cancer that I do have a choice.  Anybody else feel as I do?
Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker

Posts.Content: Jun 29, 2009 09:42AM rgiuff wrote: Interesting to hear all the responses.  Before the lumpectomy and radiation, I was so afraid that I would end up with so much less of a breast than before.  So this is actually a pleasant surprise that this is now the slightly bigger one!  And there has been no change at all in the leveI, they are both at the same level with nipples perfectly aligned, no sagging to speak of.  But I am an A cup, so maybe that's why.   And I've always worn underwires pretty much around the clock. I went back to my Rad Onc for 1 follow up visit a few weeks after the radiation ended, but since there were no further issues until now, I never went for the 3 month post follow up in Jan., thinking that it was unecessary.  Now I'm thinking of going back to see him again just to discuss this and some other symptoms I've been having occasionally, like shortness of breath.  I was blaming the tamoxifen for that but maybe it's a delayed side effect to the radiation. Which brings me to the next question, how long do you all continue to follow up with your Radiation Onc? I'm seeing my Med Onc every 3 months so maybe I could just discuss all this with him.

Posts.Content: Nov 14, 2009 04:43PM rgiuff wrote: LoriAnn, in case you haven't seen it yet, there is a thread called Natural Girls under the Alternative, Natural and Complementary forum.  Many of the women on Natural Girls are seeing naturopathic docs.   Some of them also refused to take hormonal therapy, chemo, or rads.  Many interesting discussions on that forum.  If I could afford it, I'd maybe give up the tamoxifen and go with a Naturopathic M.D myself.
Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker

Posts.Content: Aug 12, 2009 12:34PM rgiuff wrote: Eliminar, just by reading on this site in the area called Understanding Your Risk, you may get some info that will help.  From my own reading in that section, I figured that my risk, based on my early stage, well differentiated, node negative tumor, for reoccurance was about 10% after lumpectomy and radiation, and that tamoxifen theoretically reduces the risk by 50%, cuttng my risk down to 5%.  I've done 7 months of tamox, took a 6 week break because of the hot flashes and other side effects.  I'm now restarting it again just to finish out maybe a year or two, not sure yet, but pretty positive that I won't do 5 years.  I feel very ambivalent about taking it.  I also worry about long term side effects of the tamox and feel that I've also done other things to reduce my risk further, like now making exercise a regular part of my life, as well as cutting out most sugar and refined carbs, as well as many meat and dairy products because of all the hormones added to these.  I've also greatly upped my intake of cruciferous veggies, as well as other dietary changes.  You can PM me if you want to discuss this further.
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy with radiation, but no hormonal threrapy elimar PauldingMom

Posts.Content: Nov 21, 2009 12:12PM rgiuff wrote: Kendall, if you do a search on here, there is a whole thread on here about micro mets and whether or not that should be considered a positive or negative node result.  Also discussed was the question of whether or not lymph nodes should be removed, especially if chemo will be done, as theoretically, chemo would take care of cancer in the nodes anyway.  They remove further nodes for staging purposes only, but this puts you at risk for lymphedema when a lot of them are removed.  Being you are so young, and the tumor was stage 2b,  and nodes were questionable, I think chemo is going to be strongly recommended.  They may also recommend some type of ovarian suppression, to keep the hormones down.  I believe you mentioned that you  don't have kids yet, so if you want to in the future, make sure that you let the Onc know, you want to do everything you can to preserve your fertility.   And if you want to avoid bills piling up, there are plenty of Oncs out there who will probably take your insurance, so I would make sure to find one who does.
Posts.Title: recieved 2 different diagnoses today... Klawless9 swest

Posts.Content: Jul 7, 2011 03:16PM - edited Jul 7, 2011 06:35PM by rgiuff I also like the theory about the bug infestation being compared to someone starting off as a Stage IV.   The way I understand it, everyone has cancer cells floating around, but in only a small percent of the population, will these ever become a detectable mass.  So if you start off with something out of control, it makes sense that it would be that much harder to get it under control.   I wonder if studies were done comparing changes in lifestyle, such as anticancer diet vs. continuing regular diet and adding exercise in to the mix, whether this would explain why some women reoccur and some don't.   If you not only kill or starve the cells off using medication, but also change the environment in which they could grow, would this be what makes the difference?
Posts.Title: Adjvnt Therapy: Destroys or delays growth of stray BC cells? SusansGarden Omaz

Posts.Content: Jul 7, 2011 07:59PM rgiuff wrote: I also agree with those of you saying,  how do we know that it was the drug that prevented a recurrence and not that maybe it never would have recurred anyway, drugs or no drugs.  I also don't completely trust clinical trials because results can be tailored and interpreted in different ways like Susan says.  I think a lot of results obtained from studies can be coincidental.  I also read that book, "The Emperor of all Maladies" by the way.  The other thing I have an issue with is, does estrogen cause or just feed breast cancer?  I really don't believe that it causes it, but do believe that it can feed it once it's already started.  And I've never liked the idea of therapies that cut off all our estrogen supply (AIs).  I want to keep estrogen in my body as it serves many beneficial purposes.  The tamoxifen I'm OK with, because it blocks it where it needs to be blocked while other parts of the body still have it available. The other thing that makes me take the tamoxifen is reading about women who have taken it, saying how it shrank their tumors.  In my mind this means that it is doing something observable and that maybe it could benefit me.
Posts.Title: Adjvnt Therapy: Destroys or delays growth of stray BC cells? SusansGarden Omaz

Posts.Content: Aug 4, 2009 02:27PM rgiuff wrote: Great article Ivorymom.  Thanks for that link!
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy with radiation, but no hormonal threrapy elimar PauldingMom

Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2009 10:56AM rgiuff wrote: In May 2008, I had a lumpectomy on my left breast.  My breasts were small (A cup) to begin with, and the left was slightly smaller than the right, so I was worried about the cosmetic outcome.  I went through 6 weeks of radiation and worried that this would shrink it even further, so was planning on possible implants after all the treatments were done.  My Onc told me to wait several months before making any decisions about implants, which I did, and after all that, I noticed that my left breast actually seemed slightly larger than the other, maybe due to radiation and scar tissue.  Now I'm no longer interested in implants, seems too problematic.  And you really can't see any difference in my breasts.  Nipples are perfectly aligned heightwise, and my surgeon had used an oncoplastic technique, which means that she filled in the lumpectomy area with some adjoining breast tissue so that I wouldn't be left with a dent.   What also makes me glad that I went this route is that I still have my nipple sensations intact and this was also important to me.   And I didn't like the idea of taking muscle or body parts from other areas to make new breasts, as I like to work out and stay active, and prefer to keep all my tissue where it was intended to be. The surgery pain subsides within a day or two and the SNB incision was slightly more painful than the lumpectomy incision.  I was back to doing pushups within 2 weeks, but could have done them within 1, only I wanted to play it safe.  I had some numbness under my arm for several months, some of that has gone away, just a tiny bit of numbness remains..
Posts.Title: Anyone with successful Lumpectomy stories momto3 ootee

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2009 04:11PM rgiuff wrote: OTLady, what is a Van Nuys scale?  And since your doctor said the risks outweigh the benefits, even with you being estrogen and progesterone positive, I'm curious to know what stage, grade, and type of breast cancer you had.  This is the first time that I'm hearing about an Onc who decides against tamoxifen, unless he plans on prescribing some other type of hormonal therapy in place of it?
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy with radiation, but no hormonal threrapy elimar PauldingMom

Posts.Content: Jul 8, 2011 11:15AM rgiuff wrote: Chevy, articles on BC.org mention tamoxifen being used before surgery to help shrink tumors so that a woman could have a lumpectomy instead of a masectomy.  That is the tumor shrinking that I was referring to.  Sorry I'm not good at figuring out how to put links in my messages. I never heard about tamoxifen being hard on the hair follicles just like chemo.  Initially, my hair seemed to be thinning a little on tamoxifen, but could have been due to normal aging/going through menopause.  However, the past year, it seems to have thickened up a bit more and the hairdresser still says I have plenty of it all over.  If it was causing me any unacceptable side effects, like uterine issues or like your hearing loss, I would stop it in a heartbeat.  I actually have already taken a break from it earlier on for about a month due to libido/sexual issues and intolerable hot flashes, which all did improve somewhat from the break.  I refuse to start taking meds to combat the side effects of other meds or to start removing body parts just to stay on a medication that may be minimally benefitting me.
Posts.Title: Adjvnt Therapy: Destroys or delays growth of stray BC cells? SusansGarden Omaz

Posts.Content: Jan 1, 2011 07:14AM - edited Jan 1, 2011 07:17AM by rgiuff Fearless, just to clarify something.  How ER or PR positive you are doesn't mean that you have more estrogen or progesterone floating around.  It shows how much of the tumor had receptors for those hormones or how dependant on hormones it was for its growth.  It also predicts the likelihood of how beneficial hormonal therapy could be for a particular case.  If you had a low ER score for example, you'd still get hormonal therapy, but it might not be as helpful for you as for someone with a high score.  An oophorectomy would do the most to a premenopausal woman with a more advanced stage of cancer as far as cutting down on estrogen production.  Being you are already in menopause and taking the arimidex which pretty much stops all your estrogen production, I can't understand the need for removing the ovaries at all.  The only reason would be if you are really worried about ovarian cancer.  With no family history or BRCA -, I believe our risk is no greater than the general population.   As for removing the uterus, are there abnormal cells growing in there or heavy bleeding?  These are usually the reasons why this surgery would be needed.
Posts.Title: Question for ER+ ladies.... Fearless_One Fearless_One

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2010 04:37PM rgiuff wrote: Chrissy, sorry to hear you've had such a tough year.  I definitely agree that stress could have caused this in my case as well.  Physically, I had none of the risk factors.  I had my kids young, breastfed all 3 of them for many months, no family history, ate healthy etc...  But mentally, I've always had turmoil going on inside me with depression issues and many regrets over major life decisions.  I'm now making an effort to try to bring more fun and laughter into my life, which can be easier said than done.  I hope you are able to do the same and that nothing else bad happens to you.
Posts.Title: Did stress cause my BC? chrissyc

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2010 04:15PM rgiuff wrote: Jeanette, I have to agree with Deanna.  If they take 1 or a just a few sentinel nodes and it/they are clear, there is no reason to put yourself at higher risk of lymphedema by taking more.  I've seen it on some of my hospital patients and it is ugly and debilitating.  And in your shoes, I would call my doctor and insist on getting more specifics from the pathology report.  They have to put an estimated size  and type on there.  Nobody should expect you to make such a big decision with such limited information.

Posts.Content: Jun 9, 2009 06:10PM rgiuff wrote: Hi, I just found this board.  I have been a nurse since 1993.  Worked 4 years in Med-Surg 12 hr days, then 3-11 for a yr and a half, then 18 months in MICU on 12 hr. nights.  I moved to another hospital to get into L&D, and that's where I've been for 9 yrs on 12 hr nts.  I've wondered if that night shift had anything to do with my diagnosis, or if it was lack of consistent exercise, drinking a little more alcohol than recommended, or the environment of living here on Long Island.  Bottom line is, I'll never know what caused it.   But I am doing things to change my lifestyle around.  I had a lumpectomy, followed by radiation, which I worked through without a hitch, and now am on tamoxifen, and  I'm constantly rethinking whether I will stay on it or not due to side effects and worries about long term effects. I just started on an 8 hr 7-3 shift,  I work out regularly now for the past yr and a half, have cut down on alcohol, and am eating very a healthy cancer fighting type of diet.  I'm also trying to work on being more expressive, not holding my emotions in, because I think that stress had a lot to do with it.  I read something about a cancer prone personality being someone who doesn't express emotions and worries about others without taking good care of themself.  That's me and I'm trying to be a little more selfish instead of just trying to please all the time. I'm curious about other nurses with breast cancer and what you all think caused yours.
Posts.Title: Nurses with Breast Cancer Jo_Ann_K PatRN10

Posts.Content: Aug 4, 2010 12:29PM rgiuff wrote: Gunner, I'm currently on tamoxifen for over a year and a half and perimenopausal.  Now since starting the tamox, my periods come very rarely, maybe twice a year.  I always had bad PMS right before my periods, and the only benefit to being menopausal is not having that depressed feeling for several days before my period.  But I don't like the joint pains, hot flashes, more wrinkly skin, and impact on my sex life.  But I have found solutions to most of these problems.  Having ovaries out would scare me even more, not because of the surgery, but because of the after affects of surgical menopause, and the fact that recent studies are showing that removing ovaries is not such a benign thing.  Apparently, they have unknown benefits to us even after menopause.  And my fear is that oophorectomy would give me worse side effects than tamoxifen because of the sudden loss of all the hormones, not just the estrogen.  You could try the tamoxifen first before making any big decisions.  Maybe you'd find the side effects to be not so bad.  And there is a possibility that it could make your periods stop or become irregular, especially since you are close to menopause age anyway.  These are all just food for thought.  Of course, it's up to you and if you want those periods gone instantly and aren't worried too much about the possible after affects, than go for the ooph.
Posts.Title: Nurses with Breast Cancer Jo_Ann_K PatRN10

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2010 09:04AM rgiuff wrote: Don't know what stage or grade your cancer was, or how big the lump was, but if a good cosmetic outcome is possible by doing a lumpectomy, then you certainly should have that as a choice. I had thought about doing the masectomy, but in the end realized that I wanted to keep my own breast, with nipple sensation intact.  I didn't like the idea of reconstructing by taking from muscle or other body parts and implants seem to have their own problems.  If I get a reoccurrence, then I'll have to reconsider, but for now at least, I still have my own breasts and the surgery with radiation afterwards didn't feel so traumatic.
Posts.Title: Why not just keep the breast? Halah dlb823

Posts.Content: Aug 6, 2009 11:04AM rgiuff wrote: I went through the 6 week radiation treatment, finished in October, and noticed no difference at all initially.  Now, for the past 2 or 3 months, I find that the radiated breast feels heavier than the other one and it used to be the smaller breast.
Posts.Title: Radiated breast smaller? O3132W O3132W

Posts.Content: May 24, 2010 04:35PM - edited May 24, 2010 04:41PM by rgiuff Labor and Delivery nurse here,  worked nights for about 10 years, have now switched to a day shift 1 year ago.  Diagnosed 2 years ago, no chemo, had rads, now on tamoxifen since Nov 2008, perimenopausal.  My Onc laughs when I come up with suggestions or tell him I don't want certain treatments (have no desire to ever take the AIs) and he attributes it all to me being a nurse, but most of it is from the extensive research I've done on Breast cancer since being diagnosed!  I really knew nothing about the treatments before this happened to me.  I've now added 1000 IU of Vit D to my daily regimen after having a level of 27 last year, got it up to 35 this year and hopefully it's still rising.  I also drink green tea, take flaxseed and some soy, products, try to eat organic as much as I can afford, buy dairy without the growth hormones injected and do yoga and workout as much as I can.  None of this was recommended by my Onc, or known by me ahead of time, all because of reading forums on here and reading some of the scientific articles on the internet.
Posts.Title: Nurses with Breast Cancer Jo_Ann_K PatRN10
